questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless swelling under the left lower jaw for 5 months. Her 18-year-old sister has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that has been in remission for 11 years. The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows a 3 × 2 cm swelling on the left side, 4 cm below the base of the mandible and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The swelling is soft and fluctuant. It does not move with swallowing, and forced exhalation against a closed glottis does not increase the size of the swelling. Ultrasound shows a round mass with uniform low echogenicity and no internal septations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A thyroglossal duct cyst appears as a cystic, fluctuant swelling, and may have a uniformly hypoechogenic appearance on ultrasonography, as seen here. However, they are usually located in the midline of the neck (unlike the lateral neck swelling in this patient) and move upwards during swallowing.
Image Description:

There is a mass located in the patient's midline anterior cervical area near the thyroid cartilage.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cystic hygromas appear as a soft, painless, fluid-filled fluctuant swelling, they are usually located in the posterior triangle of the neck (behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle) and arise typically before the age of 2 years. A swelling that arises in the anterior triangle of the neck in a 15-year-old girl is unlikely to be a cystic hygroma.
Image Description:

Right lateral region of the neck

(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.

(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

C) INCORRECT:

Lymphadenopathy could be a sign of infection or malignancy. This patient has no signs of infection (normal complete blood count, no fever). Additionally, despite the family history of cancer, there is no evidence to suggest malignancy (e.g., weight loss) in this patient. Most importantly, enlarged lymph nodes would appear as solid, nonfluctuant swellings rather than soft, fluctuant ones.
Image Description:

A swollen superficial cervical lymph node is visible below this patient's right mandible.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a carotid body tumor may appear as a soft, painless swelling in the anterior triangle of the neck, they generally appear after 40 years of age and are usually pulsatile, making this condition an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Branchial cleft cysts typically manifest with a painless, cystic swelling that lies in the anterior triangle of the neck at a point between the upper one-third, and lower two-thirds of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is caused by failure of the second branchial cleft or cervical sinus to obliterate. This condition is usually diagnosed in late childhood or in adulthood after a previously undiagnosed cyst becomes infected.
Image Description:

The cervical sinus is formed during embryogenesis by the proliferation of the second branchial arch, which covers the 2nd–4th branchial clefts. The cervical sinus typically degenerates, however, branchial cleft cysts and fistulas may arise if these epithelial ducts persist.

F) INCORRECT:

An external laryngocele may appear as a painless, swelling in the anterior triangle. However, these swellings are nonfluctuant (because they do not contain fluid) and characteristically increase in size with a Valsalva maneuver. Laryngoceles are also 5 times more common in men. In this adolescent girl, a fluctuant swelling that does not increase in size with a Valsalva maneuver suggests a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Infantile hemangiomas appear as strawberry red or bluish lesions during infancy that generally resolve spontaneously and slowly during early childhood. They are typically noticed during the first days to months of life and would not appear in an adolescent patient, such as this 15-year-old girl.
Image Description:

Dome-shaped, crusted, red nodule on the lower left eyelid of a child. Two smaller nodules can be seen above the left eye and on the forehead.

These lesions are also referred to as strawberry hemangiomas and are usually located on the head and neck region.
questions.hint: This condition derives from the cervical sinus and is treated through complete surgical excision.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a progressive swelling of her neck for the past 6 months. She has no pain, dyspnea, or dysphagia. She is at the 60th percentile for height and the 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm cystic, nontender swelling in the midline of the neck. The swelling moves upwards with protrusion of the tongue. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.1 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Excision of the cyst, track, and hyoid bone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) may help confirm the diagnosis of a thyroglossal duct cyst or exclude differential diagnoses, other noninvasive modalities are preferred. FNA may, however, be performed in an infected thyroglossal duct cyst to obtain samples for Gram stain and culture.

B) INCORRECT:

The Sistrunk procedure involves excision of the cyst, a portion of the hyoid bone, and the descending track originating from the foramen cecum and is the standard surgical treatment for thyroglossal duct cysts. This procedure is associated with the lowest risk of recurrence as compared to less extensive resections. Although early surgical excision is recommended to prevent infection of the thyroglossal duct cyst, confirmation of the diagnosis and exclusion of the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue should occur first.

C) CORRECT:

This patient should first undergo ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis and location of the thyroid and localize possible ectopic thyroid tissue, which is often present in patients with thyroglossal duct cyst. As this ectopic tissue may be the patient's only functional thyroid tissue, ultrasonography should first be performed to evaluate the cyst architecture and its location in relation to functional ectopic or orthotopic thyroid tissue, to ensure that surgical excision of the cyst will not result in postoperative hypothyroidism. Thyroid function testing may be normal even if ectopic thyroid tissue is the only functioning tissue, but it may be useful if the thyroid gland has an abnormal appearance or is not visualized on ultrasound.
Image Description:

Neck ultrasound (transverse section)

A circular, sharply demarcated, hypoechoic lesion (green overlay) is visible dorsal to the thyroid gland.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan would detect the cyst and provide valuable information for planning the surgery, but it would also expose the child to radiation. There are other sensitive imaging modalities that allow exposure to radiation to be avoided. A CT of the neck with contrast is often the preferred imaging modality for evaluating thyroglossal duct cyst in adults. It is also recommended in the evaluation of a suspected neck malignancy or a retropharyngeal or deep neck abscess.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; a: axial plane; b: sagittal plane)

A hypodense mass (green overlay) with a fluid density value (mean 20 HU) is present anterior to the hyoid bone (arrows).

E) INCORRECT:

Simple excision of the thyroglossal duct cysts is not the preferred approach to removal due to the high risk of recurrence. However, prior to any surgical intervention, the diagnosis should be confirmed and the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue excluded.

F) INCORRECT:

While thyroid scintigraphy can be used to rule out ectopic thyroid tissue, it is unnecessary to perform if the imaging method of choice reveals normal thyroid architecture and thyroid function testing is normal. Additionally, exposing children to radionuclide material should be avoided, if possible.
questions.hint: A nontender cystic midline swelling that moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue indicates a thyroglossal duct cyst.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

B) INCORRECT:

A ranula is a mucocele arising from the sublingual gland that manifests as a translucent, dome-shaped, blue mass below the tongue. Although large lesions can cause swelling of the neck, this would occur lateral to the midline and would not move upwards with tongue protrusion or swallowing.

C) INCORRECT:

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.

D) INCORRECT:

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).
Image Description:

Right lateral region of the neck

(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.

(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

E) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

F) INCORRECT:

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.
questions.hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl with a history of intermittent asthma presents with a neck mass that her mother noticed several days ago. The girl has also had a runny nose and cough for the past several days, which are starting to improve.
Her vital signs are normal for her age, and she appears well. Physical examination reveals a midline mass, 2 cm x 2 cm in diameter, just below the hyoid bone, that is not tender or erythematous. The mass moves when the patient swallows.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphatic malformations are usually diagnosed in the neonatal period or by prenatal ultrasound. They are typically located in the posterior triangle of the neck, most often on the left, and are spongy, nontender, and mobile. Ultrasound, MRI, or both should be performed before any treatment is recommended. Fine-needle aspiration should be avoided given the high risk for bleeding into the mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital dermoid cysts, which are caused by epithelial entrapment of the deep tissue, are often midline and look and feel very similar to thyroglossal duct cysts; however, they tend to be more superficial, can be located anywhere in the midline neck, and do not move when the patient swallows. Ultrasound may help distinguish thyroglossal duct cysts from dermoid cysts, although even this test may not be able to differentiate between the two. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for either condition, although dermoid cyst excision does not entail removal of the hyoid bone.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation and recent history are most consistent with a thyroglossal duct cyst. Thyroglossal duct cysts are midline, anterior lesions that may manifest after an upper respiratory tract infection. Because a thyroglossal duct cyst is connected to the hyoid bone, it may move when the patient swallows or protrudes their tongue. Most thyroglossal duct cysts surface during childhood or adolescence, but they may also appear during early adulthood. The appropriate treatment is to completely excise the cyst, the middle portion of the hyoid bone, and a cuff of tongue-base tissue superior to the hyoid.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a child with a midline, anterior neck mass that appeared after an upper respiratory tract infection and that moves upon swallowing is thyroglossal duct cyst.

D) INCORRECT:

Branchial cleft cysts are seen along the anterior cervical chain, along the sternocleidomastoid, to the right or left of midline. The most common branchial cleft cyst is a second branchial cleft cyst, originating from the tonsil.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid nodules are rare in children and, given the location of the thyroid gland, would manifest lower in the midline neck than the hyoid bone. They also tend to occur to the right or left of midline.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with a history of speech delay presents to the emergency department (ED) with recurrent left neck swelling. He has had no fevers and is otherwise well. He speaks very loudly during the interview, and his parents state that he often asks them to turn up the volume on the television. The mother reports that she had neck surgery as a child but does not have any further details.
On physical examination, the patient is afebrile and has normal vital signs and normal tympanic membranes. He has a 3-cm x 2-cm area of soft-tissue swelling on the left neck with no overlying erythema, no tenderness to palpation, and no warmth to the touch. Preauricular skin tags are evident bilaterally.
MRI of the neck reveals a left branchial cleft cyst.
In addition to a hearing test and referral to an otolaryngologist, which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain should be used to detect masses, abnormalities in the ventricles, and other structural anomalies. In this case, the patient’s constellation of findings is most consistent with BOR syndrome, and therefore a renal ultrasound is more appropriate. If no other cause for the hearing impairment is found, then additional studies may be warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (for which classic bone findings might be evident on a skeletal survey) is sometimes associated with hearing loss, but not with branchial cleft cysts. Furthermore, it tends to manifest at a younger age.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography and ophthalmology evaluation are recommended for patients with suspected CHARGE syndrome or Townes-Brocks syndrome, but they are not indicated for diagnosis of BOR syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a newly diagnosed branchial cyst and likely has hearing loss, given his history of speech delay, his tendency to talk loudly, and his repeated requests for higher volumes. In addition to further evaluation of the hearing loss, renal and bladder ultrasonography should be performed to evaluate for renal anomalies associated with branchio-oto-renal (BOR) syndrome.

BOR syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hearing loss, auricular malformations, branchial arch anomalies, and renal anomalies. It affects 1 in 40,000 infants and is associated with mutations in the EYA1, SIX5, and SIX1 genes. Diagnosis is based on clinical criteria, including at least 3 of the following major criteria or 2 major and 2 minor criteria. Individuals with an affected first-degree relative need only one major criterion for diagnosis.

Major criteria:

• Second branchial arch anomalies
• Deafness
• Preauricular pits
• Auricular malformation
• Renal anomalies

Minor criteria:

• External auditory canal anomalies
• Middle-ear anomalies
• Preauricular tags
• Facial asymmetry
• Palate abnormalities

This patient may have a family history, given the mother’s childhood neck surgery, but he also has at least two possible major criteria (deafness and branchial arch abnormalities) and one minor criterion (preauricular tags). The next step is to evaluate for renal abnormalities associated with BOR syndrome, which include renal agenesis, hypoplasia, dysplasia, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, calyceal cyst or diverticulum, caliectasis, pyelectasis, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux.

Hearing loss is a symptom of many genetic syndromes, including Townes-Brocks syndrome (which is characterized by branchiogenic anomalies, hearing loss, congenital heart disease, preaxial polydactyly, and imperforate anus) and CHARGE syndrome (which is characterized by coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, retarded growth and development, genital anomalies, and ear anomalies). Although each of these syndromes may be associated with renal anomalies, neither is associated with branchial cleft anomalies, making them distinct from BOR syndrome.

Key learning point: The combination of hearing loss and branchial cleft anomalies in a child should trigger evaluation for renal abnormalities associated with branchio-oto-renal syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography and ophthalmology evaluation are recommended for patients with suspected CHARGE syndrome or Townes-Brocks syndrome, but they are not indicated for diagnosis of BOR syndrome.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old girl presents with a draining pit in the right mid-neck. Her parents state that the pit has been present her entire life but began draining about 2 weeks ago. On examination, there is a small area of swelling underlying the pit that is tender to palpation. An ultrasound reveals a cystic mass 2 cm in size just superior to the pit.
Antibiotics are prescribed, and the patient subsequently follows up. The pit is no longer draining, but the mass is still palpable.
What is the best next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: A second, extended course of antibiotic therapy
Surgical excision of the skin pit and underlying tract and cyst

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although cat-scratch disease should be considered in the differential diagnosis for a pediatric neck mass, the features in this case (including the duration of symptoms and location of the lesion) are more consistent with a superinfected congenital lesion. Cat-scratch disease typically causes cervical lymphadenopathy, not swelling in the midline of the neck.

B) INCORRECT:

Although mycobacterial infections in the head and neck can lead to fistula formation and drainage from the skin, this patient’s skin pit has been present since birth, which is more consistent with a congenital lesion. Furthermore, if a diagnosis of tuberculosis was being considered in a child < 2 years of age, a purified protein derivative skin test would be more appropriate than an interferon-gamma release assay.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has already completed one course of antibiotics, and the infection of the underlying congenital lesion has improved. A second course of antibiotics would not address the underlying branchial anomaly.

D) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration does not have a role in the management of branchial anomalies in children.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a second branchial cleft anomaly, the most common congenital branchial anomaly. These anomalies can manifest as an isolated cyst, or they can have a connection to either the skin alone (forming a sinus) or both the skin and the pharynx (forming a fistula). Overall, sinuses are more common than cysts, which are in turn more common than fistulas. Second branchial cleft anomalies can have a tract that courses to the tonsillar fossa, and complete excision — including the pit and surrounding skin, the tract, and the cyst — is needed to reduce recurrence risk.

Key learning point: A second branchial cleft anomaly that develops a draining sinus tract should be managed with complete surgical excision of the skin pit and the underlying sinus tract and cyst.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with a painless swelling in the central neck that has gradually enlarged over the past two months. The swelling is located just below the hyoid bone and visibly elevates when he protrudes his tongue or swallows. He is otherwise healthy. Examination shows a soft, mobile midline mass with no associated pain, erythema, or difficulty breathing.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystic hygromas are lymphatic malformations typically found in the lateral neck, often in the posterior triangle. They do not elevate with tongue protrusion or swallowing. These lesions are usually identified in infancy or early childhood, not in adolescence. The midline location and movement with swallowing are not characteristic of a cystic hygroma.

B) CORRECT:

A thyroglossal duct cyst manifests as a midline neck mass, often located just below the hyoid bone. It results from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryologic remnant from the thyroid gland's descent. The mass typically elevates with tongue protrusion and swallowing due to its connection to the tongue base. This condition is common in children and adolescents and usually presents as a painless, slowly enlarging mass. The absence of pain, erythema, or respiratory symptoms aligns with the typical presentation of a thyroglossal duct cyst.

Key learning point: A midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, a congenital anomaly due to the persistence of the thyroglossal duct.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are midline masses that arise from ectodermal tissue. They do not elevate with tongue protrusion or swallowing, as they lack a connection to the tongue or hyoid bone. The movement of the mass with swallowing and tongue protrusion suggests a lesion related to the thyroglossal duct, not a dermoid cyst.

D) INCORRECT:

Branchial cleft cysts are lateral neck masses, often near the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not elevate with tongue protrusion or swallowing, as they lack a connection to the tongue or hyoid bone. The midline location and movement with swallowing in this patient are inconsistent with a branchial cleft cyst.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to your clinic because of a progressive swelling in her neck over the past 6 months. She has no pain, dyspnea, or dysphagia. Her mother has hypothyroidism. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 60th percentile for height and the 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a 3-cm cystic, nontender swelling in the midline of the neck that moves upward with protrusion of the tongue. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is normal. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.1 mIU/L (0.34–5.60). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Excision of the cyst, track, and hyoid bone.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple excision of the thyroglossal duct cysts is not the preferred approach to removal due to the high risk of recurrence. However, prior to any surgical intervention, the diagnosis should be confirmed and the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue excluded.

B) INCORRECT:

While thyroid scintigraphy can be used to rule out ectopic thyroid tissue, it is unnecessary to perform if the imaging method of choice reveals normal thyroid architecture and thyroid function testing is normal. Additionally, exposing children to radionuclide material should be avoided, if possible.

C) CORRECT:

This patient should first undergo ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis and location of the thyroid and localize possible ectopic thyroid tissue, which is often present in patients with thyroglossal duct cyst. As this ectopic tissue may be the patient's only functional thyroid tissue, ultrasonography should first be performed to evaluate the cyst architecture and its location in relation to functional ectopic or orthotopic thyroid tissue, to ensure that surgical excision of the cyst will not result in postoperative hypothyroidism. Thyroid function testing may be normal even if ectopic thyroid tissue is the only functioning tissue, but it may be useful if the thyroid gland has an abnormal appearance or is not visualized on ultrasound.

Key learning point: Neck ultrasonography is the initial diagnostic test for a thyroglossal duct cyst to confirm the diagnosis and ensure normal thyroid tissue is present before surgical excision.
Image Description:

Neck ultrasound (transverse section)

A circular, sharply demarcated, hypoechoic lesion (green overlay) is visible dorsal to the thyroid gland.

D) INCORRECT:

While fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) may help confirm the diagnosis of a thyroglossal duct cyst or exclude differential diagnoses, other noninvasive modalities are preferred. FNA may, however, be performed in an infected thyroglossal duct cyst to obtain samples for Gram stain and culture.

E) INCORRECT:

The Sistrunk procedure involves excision of the cyst, a portion of the hyoid bone, and the descending track originating from the foramen cecum and is the standard surgical treatment for thyroglossal duct cysts. This procedure is associated with the lowest risk of recurrence as compared to less extensive resections. Although early surgical excision is recommended to prevent infection of the thyroglossal duct cyst, confirmation of the diagnosis and exclusion of the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue should occur first.
questions.hint: A nontender cystic midline swelling that moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue indicates a thyroglossal duct cyst.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to your clinic because of a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves upward when she protrudes her tongue. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

B) CORRECT:

A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

Key learning point: A thyroglossal cyst presents as a painless, midline neck mass that moves upward with tongue protrusion due to its connection to the base of the tongue.

C) INCORRECT:

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.

D) INCORRECT:

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).

E) INCORRECT:

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.
questions.hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with left sided neck swelling is brought to the ED by foster parents, having been placed in foster care yesterday. Photographs provided by the infant's grandmother suggest the swelling has been present for at least a month. The infant is afebrile, feeding well, and breathing comfortably. Examination shows a soft, nontender, compressible mass in the left posterior triangle of the neck without erythema, warmth, or overlying skin changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Branchial cleft cysts typically occur along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and are firm, well circumscribed, and noncompressible. Branchial cleft cysts are less likely to manifest in the posterior triangle or manifest as soft, diffuse swelling.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive lymphadenopathy manifests with small, firm, sometimes tender nodes following infection. The absence of fever, tenderness, or preceding illness makes this diagnosis unlikely in an afebrile infant.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroglossal duct cysts usually occur in the midline and move with swallowing or tongue protrusion. This lesion is located in the posterior triangle of the neck, making another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A deep neck abscess typically manifests acutely with pain, fever, and erythema. This infant is afebrile and appears well, making an infectious process unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Lymphangioma is a congenital lymphatic malformation commonly located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma manifests as a soft, nontender, compressible swelling that may enlarge gradually. Identifying a cystic hygroma in the ED is important to assess for airway compromise or dysphagia and to arrange imaging and surgical consult for definitive management.
